case_vignette: A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of progressive left leg pain for 2 months, which has started to interfere with his sleep. His mother has been giving him ibuprofen at night for “growing pains,” but his symptoms have not improved. One week before the pain started, the patient was hit in the thigh by a baseball, which caused his leg to become red and swollen for several days. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows marked tenderness along the left mid-femur. His gait is normal. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 21,000/mm3 and an ESR of 68 mm/h. An x-ray of the left lower extremity shows multiple lytic lesions in the middle third of the femur, and the surrounding cortex is covered by several layers of new bone. A biopsy of the left femur shows small round blue cells.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Hematology and Oncology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having progressive pain in my left leg for 2 months and it's been so bad that it's been keeping me up at night.
Have you had any other symptoms such as fever, weight loss, or difficulty breathing?
No, just the leg pain.
Have you had any history of blood clots or deep vein thrombosis?
No history of blood clots or deep vein thrombosis.
Have you had any recent surgeries or injuries?
Yes, I was hit in the thigh by a baseball one week before the pain started.
Have you had any family history of blood clots or deep vein thrombosis?
There's no mention of a family history of blood clots or deep vein thrombosis in my information.
Final Diagnosis: Deep Vein Thrombosis.
